content: Thanks for your help David, but it seems that it's TalkTalk that don't want to allow it. They said they don't support Thunderbird and the old tisacli email unless I pay them £12 per month to use it or I have to use their email service; which is rubbish! Wondered if by downloading the new Thunderbird version that would help? I'm not very techy but can ask one of my daughters to help. Every time I open up Thunderbird it asks to add my password on imap.tiscali.co.uk but it doesn't work. Thanks Gill
creator: gillandbrenda

content:
My inference from a couple of websites is that talktalk may no longer allow use of email accounts without a talktalk subscription. If that is true, your only choice would be to subscribe to keep the account. I gleaned that possibility from this URL: https://bigtechquestion.com/2021/09/17/online/why-is-my-tiscali-email-not-working-anymore/ 

However, I also notice a possible setup here:

https://www.getmailbird.com/setup/access-tiscali-it-via-imap-smtp

My suggestion is to attempt the recommended setup, reporting errors here if needed. I suggest you ask one of your daughters to speak directly with talktalk, as it isn't a matter of their supporting Thunderbird, it's a matter of whether they allow users to access the Tisgali account with a POP or IMAP email client. I respect that they may refuse to offer assistance on a product that isn't theirs; the question is whether they allow any access other than through their website. There may be simple miscommunication here.

But do try the suggested setup. It may work.
creator: davidsk

content:
I'm not sure it's going to work with imap.tiscali.co.uk as the incoming server. Try using the settings suggested by Tiscali.

Incoming IMAP: mail.talktalk.net on port 993, SSL/TLS, normal password authentication, User Name = email address; outgoing smtp.talktalk.net on port 587, STARTTLS, normal password authentication, User Name = email address.

https://community.talktalk.co.uk/t5/Articles/Email-settings-to-access-TalkTalk-emails/ta-p/2204399

https://community.talktalk.co.uk/t5/Email/Cannot-Add-a-Tiscali-Account-in-Thunderbird/td-p/2965831

Talktalk saying they don't support TB means they won't offer support in using it, but doesn't mean that TB can't be used with their service.

content:
I got some remote help with this problem and they were able to fix it!

Yes, you had sent messages set to sort messages as "threaded", I then changed this to "unthreaded" so all messages would be separated and not linked by who you sent to.

This was changed under View > Sort by > Unthreaded

content:
translated: After a new login I can no longer find my address book! What should I do?

When you say 'after a new login' - do you mean you created a new profile or a new existing mail account or you updated your mail account password ?

Thunderbird starts up when you click on the shortcut icon to start Thunderbird - there is no login, so I'm trying to understand what you mean.

Did Thunderbird start up and look empty so you had to create a mail account for your email address?

When you select 'Menu icon' > 'Tools' > 'Address book' OR click on the 'Address Book shortcut icon in the 'spaces Toolbar, the 'Address Book' should open in a new tab.

What do you see? Do you see 'Personal Address Book' and 'Collected Addresses' in left pane ? Do you see those address books but they are empty ?

What OS are you using ? Linux, MAC or Windows ? What version of Thunderbird are you using?
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
calgarylocalguy said
I've never created filters directly in TB to the best of my recollection.

Don't recollect, check.

Nothing is worse than assumption, especially in this sort of context. I have seen far to many folk on this forum looking for an add-on they forgot they installed years ago that provided some function and now it is missing or complaining about a filter they created 10 years ago and also forgot. Use the tools menu to access message filters (note they has a drop down in the initial dialog to select the account to list). All accounts you have in Thunderbird need to be checked for a filter accessing that folder.

content:
mostly when global search does not show the email after finding it that solution is https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/rebuilding-global-database

Note that is you have an antivirus product or streaming backup interacting with the profile folder while it is in use then updates to that global database are quite prone to failure, mostly because the other product locks access to the file for about the amount of time your get between each mail fetch.

Never allow scanning in the Thunderbird profile while the program is running. Never allow a backup including the Thunderbird profile to occur while Thunderbird is running. Never place the Thunderbird profile in the my documents/ documents storage location Never place the Thunderbird profile in a location that is syncronised to another location, either locally or in the cloud.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
The correct AT&T POP server is inbound.att.net on 995, SSL/TLS, normal password authentication, but you must use a secure mail key in TB in place of the account password:

https://www.att.com/support/article/dsl-high-speed/KM1010523/
creator: sfhowes

creator: drumfamily

content: I believe ATT requires a separate password for email clients, different from the one you use online. Please review these URLs for more info: https://www.att.com/support/article/dsl-high-speed/KM1010523/ https://www.att.com/support/article/email-support/KM1240308/
creator: davidsk

content:
Create a secure mail key on the AT&T site and use it in TB in place of the account password:

https://www.att.com/support/article/dsl-high-speed/KM1010523/

You might still encounter failed connections due to the outdated security protocols in XP, let alone the obsolete ones in TB 52. Consider switching to a used W10 PC (starting at $100).

content:
Remove all entries from Saved Passwords in Settings/Privacy & Security, confirm the incoming and outgoing server settings with the link in my first reply, restart TB, enter the secure mail key when asked for a password, check the box to have it saved in Settings.

If it suddenly stopped working, maybe your antivirus (name?) updated and became incompatible with TB. Or, maybe there is some temporary issue with AT&T (although I haven't seen reports on this forum).

content:
It's not possible to send without a password, unless you have wrong, non-secure smtp settings, or possibly there is a password manager attached to your antivirus (which you haven't named) that intercepts TB connections.

Option 1 does not delete the mail:

http://kb.mozillazine.org/Recovering_deleted_mail_accounts

I suggest you create a new profile with Profile Manager, add the account by entering the correct settings (Manual config.), and worry about recovering data from older profiles later, once the account is working.

http://kb.mozillazine.org/Profile_Manager#Windows

content: Close TB, open a profile folder, open the Mail subfolder, where you should see a subfolder named outbound.att-1.net, or outbound.att-2.net, or something similar. The dates on the subfolders will indicate which ones are current or past storage locations. Inside one of those folders there should be an mbox file named Sent (no extension) that contains previous sent messages. Copy Sent (rename if necessary to e.g. SentOLD) to the Mail/Local Folders location of the new, active profile. Restart TB and find the folder under Local Folders in the Folder Pane.

creator: joelhornstein

content:
The current TB can import .mab files, but for TB 52, overwriting the existing abook.mab with one from another profile should work, as long as TB is closed during the copy.

There is an add-on that can import .mab files, such as abook.mab and history.mab, for TB 52:

MoreFunctionsForAddressBook 1.0b8

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/installing-addon-thunderbird

creator: MattAuSupport

content: Do you have an anti virus scanning outgoing mail? That can make things incredibly slow to the point of timeouts occurring. Antivirus settings to "scan encrypted connections" can also be a significant point of failure. as encrypted connections scanning involves intercepting, decrypting, scanning, re-encrypting, and returning the data to the connection stream in basically the same way a man in the middle hack occurs. This is a very slow and CPU expensive process which is supposedly transparent but not always fast enough..
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
This is a support forum for Thunderbird not add-ons. Each has their own support. The download page for the add-on named shows this link for support https://github.com/cleidigh/printing-tools-ng/issues

I just installed the add-on and it added a tab with the install with detailed instruction on how to use the add-on. Have you read this information? If you have closed it go to the add-on manager in the tools menu, select the wrench in the add-ons name in the list of installed add-ons and look at the settings. Clicking any of the (in my case orange question marks) reopens the tab selecting the information on that page relevant to the question mark.

As far as I can see all settings are contained in the dialog that opens when you click the wrench. The site shows it as looking like this https://addons.thunderbird.net/user-media/previews/full/207/207016.png
